annotation.TEXT: Enker is easily the toughest of the Mega Man Killers, if only for his insane damage output. The shots created from his charging attack can result in a three hit kill, meaning your top priority is to essentially never get hit by them during this fight (this is a lot easier said than done). After fighting him several times however, I think I finally found a proper strategy for dealing with this...

Primal Man's stage has a slightly different gimmick for its first half: An on-rails section with several enemies to contend with. Just to note, for some reason I had a bit of slow-down in this area when trying to record it. In-game, this section moves a bit faster than how it's seen here.

That is, to run directly into him. No, I'm serious: Taking contact damage from Enker himself is a far less painful option than getting hit by the charged shots from his spear. If you bump into him at the right time (considering how little the invincibility frames last in this game), it'll ensure that you won't be hit by any of his projectiles.

Even if the slowdown does help out a bit, I'm still not particularly fond of this section. Some of the enemies here are nearly impossible kill unless you have a decently strong weapon or shoot them in the right spot (hitting the balloons on most minor enemies will instant-kill them). More-so however, it seems completely up to luck whether or not you get hit depending on how the enemies move (in some cases, it seems downright impossible to avoid taking damage).

A few of the other hazards have some weird quirks to them as well. Some of the crushers, for example, will actually kill you if you bump your head into the top of them. This seems to mostly happen with the ones stationed over pits, but it's still a bit jarring when compared to how they would usually function.

As intimidating as he might seem at first, Clamp Man is actually pretty tame when compared to some of the other bosses. His pattern is easy enough to get used to, and he can actually stun himself with the blocks he spawns from the ceiling. The only tricky thing about him is that his clamp projectiles can lock you in place for a few seconds, leaving you open to attacks.

With all the letters collected, we now have access to Beat. Unlike in the official games, Beat actually doesn't have an energy bar (he has unlimited use in this game). Beat will automatically attack the closest enemy to you, but you can't use charged shots while he's out. He'll also pick up items and bring them to you, and while helpful at first...he does have a rather bad tendency of dropping things into pits and spikes depending on where you're standing.

This is something I probably should have brought up in the first video, but considering the position of that Hammer Joe and those spikes, I think now is as good of a time as any to mention this: This game actually follows Mega Man 1 spike rules. Even if you have invincibility frames, you'll still die if you happen to touch them in any way. At this point, I don't think I need to elaborate on why this is a bad idea (especially combined with the knock-back in this game).

Top Man's platforms, while certainly an interesting addition, feel a bit...weird - or at least, they do when they're positioned directly next to walls. I was honestly a bit worried that I would suddenly clip through these first two. Thankfully, the other ones aren't stationed in similar positions.

Primal Man himself is actually pretty easy, even though I do a terrible job of demonstrating such. His general strategy to jump around a lot and throw "exploding coconuts" at you (which honestly look more like cookies at first glance). It's generally pretty easy to tell what he's going to do next, but much like Ciper and Illusion Man, this fight can easily turn annoying if he decides to spam a certain move (specifically where he leaps off-screen and throws projectiles at you, during which you won't be able to hurt him).

Time to deal with the last of the Mega Man Killers. Interestingly enough, Enker's stage is actually more moderate in length when compared to Ballade and Punk's. It also has a few strange quirks to it, especially when it comes to its primary gimmick.

The bombs in this stage are apparently randomized in whether or not they'll fall in certain places. This can be rather annoying at times, especially considering the inconsistencies of when these bombs trigger (sometimes they'll fall if you get next to their spawn points, and other times they'll only show up after you've gone slightly past them).

There's one other thing to note about this rail-section, although I'm not sure if it's intentional or just a glitch. If you hold down the jump button here, Mega Man will continually leap into the air (even though you can't do this in any of the standard platforming sections of the game). I personally see this as a bad thing, if only due to the final jump of this segment - where you can easily mess it up by simply holding the jump button for too long.

Thankfully, your reward for beating this fight is pretty awesome. The Enker Lance actually replicates Enker's charging attack to some extent, sending out several shots at the same time. While some of the shots do have the tendency to pass through certain enemies, this generally seems to happen at short range. At long range however, this thing easily becomes the best weapon in the game, as it's capable of one-shoting nearly every enemy around.

Clamp Ring isn't exactly the strongest weapon in the game, but it's still incredibly useful for its other defining trait: Hitting an enemy with it will lock them in place for a few moments, which also lets you to pass by them without taking contact damage. It doesn't work on every enemy, but it can really help out if you want to bypass something that the minuscule invincibility frames won't allow you to.

Primal Bomb is the main weapon capable of blowing up certain walls in this game. It has decent damage output and firepower somewhat on-par with Ballade Missile, but it also seems to have a slightly lower than usual ammo count when compared to some of the other weapons.

"Gangly Bass," as some have taken to calling him, is a bit of nuisance. Avoiding him is more of a pain than it needs to be, given that the only reliable way to do so seems to be to slide underneath him as he's jumping (and yes, I understand Bass is taller than Mega Man to begin with, but the pool-noodle limbs he's sporting here is a bit much).

After beating all of the main RM's, Bass shows up for a final intermission before moving on to Wily's fortress. Bass' stage itself is relatively short, though it also introduces the Copy-Robots - enemies that mimic one Robot Master each from MM1 to 6. While it's definitely a neat enemy, they can be a bit of a hassle due to how frequent and how random their copied attacks come out (hence, why I use the Clamp Ring to bypass most of them).
